channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: PWC 256
item.description: Like every week, explore the power of Perl4 and old Python.

item.title: Matching and zipping
item.description: It is rare event when you get to see one liner in Python. Thanks for your contribution.

item.title: Maximum Strings
item.description: Raku and JavaScript are the choosen one this week. You must checkout to get the reason.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #256
item.description: Dudn't know about mesh function. Thanks for sharing knowledge with us.

item.title: Pairs, sriap and MsEtRrGiEngs
item.description: The analysis section of the post is the highlight for me every week. Highly recommended.

item.title: Merge the Maximum String Pairs
item.description: I got the taste of reverse and flip in Raku during my early days with Raku. Thanks for sharing the details.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 256
item.description: Master of one-liners in Perl, sharing yet another special one. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Valentine's Challenge
item.description: Thanks for sharing the inner details of zip. All Raku fans must checkout this.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 256: Merge Strings
item.description: A detailed discussion talking about Raku magics. Highly recommended.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 256: Maximum Pairs
item.description: No more magic, pure core solutions in Perl and Raku. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Zippairs
item.description: Compact yet elegant solutions in Perl. Cool, keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 256
item.description: Method chaining in Raku makes the code so beatiful. You can easily come up with one liner.

item.title: Merged Maximum
item.description: Every week we get to learn something new in Raku. This week was 'roundrobin'. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: TWC256
item.description: Clever use of map in Perl make this solution worth checking. Keep it up great work.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 256
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Maximum Pairs" and "Merge Strings" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 257
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Smaller than Current" and "Reduced Row Echelon". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Codeforces Command Lines
item.description: For all Perl fans, if you are into competitive programming then you should give this a try.

item.title: Will You Lose Your Job to AI?
item.description: Not specific to Perl but worth every second of yours. The topic is something you do not want to miss.

item.title: Perl Steering Council Meetings
item.description: As you get weekly PSC updates here but what if you want historical updates. This website presents this in user friendly layout.

item.title: PSC #136 2024-02-15
item.description: Another weekly update from the Perl Steering Council. Thank you PSC for all the hard work.

item.title: CPAN Security Group
item.description: Welcome to the CPAN Security Group. This is a community effort for supporting and responding to security incidents on CPAN.

item.title: TPRC 2024 Call For Papers is now open!
item.description: Time to make first move and submit your ideas for talk. First timers are also welcome.

item.title: UK Remote Perl Programmer for Leading Enterprise Tech Publication
item.description: Our client is a global leader in the enterprise technology publishing industry, providing audiences worldwide with stimulating perspectives and unique news on enterprise tech that matters today and tomorrow. They are seeking a talented Perl programmer to manage the full life-cycle of software projects on a remote basis.

item.title: #656 - Perl Conference
item.description:
Hi there,

Did you get the opportunity to attend YAPC::Hiroshima?

Looking at whatever news is out in public about the conference, it appears to be a big success. A big round of applause to everyone involved. Makoto Nozaki shared his experience in the blog post. There were regular updates shared on Twitter profiles e.g. kobaken and yapcjapan. Japan is one of few places that I always wanted to visit. I still remember when I was in college my mom asked me she wanted to see Tokyo city. I casually promised her that time. But when I moved to England she kept reminding me about my promise but for health reason she couldn't travel. I was first introduced to the city when I watched the movie Love in Tokyo. I think YAPC Japan would be the perfect excuse to fulfill my mom's wish. Israel is also one place that I would like to visit once in my life time and meet Gabor Szabo in person.

How about upcoming TPRC 2024 in Las Vegas?

I remember when it was annonced at the end of conferece in Toronto last year, there was big cheers all around. I could feel the positive energy. There was a call for volunteer and presentation. If I managed to find time and health permit then I would definite go to Las Vegas. I am sure it is going to beat the Toronto experience. I would submit the talk only when I am 100% sure to travel. I really miss the similar gatherings in Europe. Talking about conference, what's happening to London Perl Workshop? Don't you miss LPW? I honestly hope it happens this year and we get to meet local champions. It is the only time, I get to meet my idols like Neil Bowers and Dave Cross. There is also a friend of mine, Theo van HoeselLPW and London Perl Mongers meetup, I miss him. I remember during one such meetup he gave short presentation on Iphone iOS scripting. I simply loved it. His ability to present difficult topic looks easy, is commendable. Let's bring back the golden moments.

Back to reality, the schools are open today after a week long holiday here in London. Too much trouble, I wonder how parents cope up with this routine. I just go with the flow, no choice. You look after yourself and loved ones. Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: editorial
